comments.commentBody: I don't envy their tough decisions. Balancing security with freedom is difficult. Especially when precedents are few. One aspect should be that outside the USA, there are rules related to warfare with terrorist groups and what is permitted, especially in coordination with our allies. In those cases, the laws of the country where the terrorist is living could help guide our choices. The problem is that we want to capture and get intelligence from terrorists, but other than that would have probably preferred the more expeditious result of death on the "battlefield". However, once a terrorist is brought to USA territory, we'd better have a plan to prosecute in either a military or civilian court. It is not acceptable to hold people indefinitely without charge within our borders. The problem with the Bush administration is that 1) they believed in torture which is not a reliable means of gathering intelligence; 2) they didn't adequately define how they were going to prosecute the captured terrorists from the start. Bush and Cheney did not lead our country well, both domestically and in foreign policy.

Agree with #12. Given the trends at work here, it is time to start a massive national investment in alternative forms of transportation, such as walking, biking and transit. Doing that is just about the only thing that has been proven to put large numbers of people back to work, since it involves real labor on a block-by-block basis.

Unfortunately, Congress's stimulus package took the wrong approach, spending only a tiny fraction on these things and primarily using the opportunity to provide more and more subsidies for massive corporate entities (e.g., R&D, highway construction firms, homebuilder tax credits, etc.).

With the Cartwright case, I might suggest that the employer's expectations were below the mark.  What I'm seeing is that as managers who had grown comfortable in near-lifetime careers leave, they are being replaced with people who are more responsive and have broader visions of their roles, leading to a more dynamic organization.

We will never get that much-needed oil pipeline if we keep putting people on trial.  They're standing in the way of progress.  Geneva Convention rules, the Bill of Rights, and Habeous Corpus are all fine, in theory, but we really need that oil for next quarter's dividend payments.
Welcome to globalization!
The only war Obama is fighting is against our allies.

Clearly, President Obama has abdicated the moral and legal leadership that he promised throughout his campaign.  He is weak.  The United States has nothing to say to despots and even killers like the LRA in the Congo about rule of law.  How can we preach rule of law when we don't practice it?  This is very sad and it has bothersome implications about the rule of law even in America.
Indictment, presentment, or grand jury. Abandon B/C (Bush/Cheney) methodology.

What tactics against fighting terrorism? Whether or not to capitulate now and claim victory? Whether or not to even call it terrorism or a human caused disasters? Whether or not to continue the apology tour for America's perceived transgressions? Whether or not to blame America for every terrorist Army psychiatrist who butchers soldiers on military installations?
I have yet to see this administration actually fight terrorism, let alone be divided on the tactics.

This will be a defining moment for the Obama Administration. Will they come down on the side of "rule of law" and of Constitutional supremacy, or will they choose "rule of men"?

Supporters are watching, avidly.

"So with no consensus, the legal team decided on a tactical approach. For as long as possible they would try to avoid that hard question. They changed the subject by instead asking courts to agree that people like Mr. Bensayah, looked at from another angle, had performed functions that made them effectively part of the terrorist organization — and so were clearly detainable."
More smoke and mirrors from the Obama administration. They keep hoping that the public isn't noticing the PR game they're playing with national security. This makes them far worse than the Bushies, who at least completely believed in what they were doing to keep the US safe.

the US  Gov has to use any mean  necessary to keep the country safe. those people have no rights. they want inflict serious damage similar to 9/11 .detention without trial is necssary in sme cases . i strongly agree for harsh treatment for terror suspect

This whole detainee debate obscures a more pressing and troubling issue: the wholesale violation of human and civil rights against American citizens, right here at home, by ongoing,ideologically-motivated Bush-legacy programs of personal destruction that involve physical torture and impairment as well as financial and career sabotage.

When will the Obama administration get a grip on a rogue bureaucracy still run by constitution-disrespecting Bush holdovers? Please read this article by this mainstream journalist -- whose work has not be challenged or refuted by any government official:

http://nowpublic.com... OR NowPublic.com/scrivener RE: "U.S. Silenty..." and "Gestapo USA."
"Men are like shingles - when one falls off, there's a dozen more ready to take his place!" -- PRR foreman

Does no one see how much damage is being done in this process to the middle class? People have worked for decades to rise to a decent level, taken on debt based on those salaries, and now are working for far less, with little prospect of ever returning to that higher level. I too, have been willing to work for far less, in a position of less responsibility, happy to do so for the sake of a paycheck. But my family is now set back for years, probably permanently, because of it.

I don't feel overqualified for or underemployed by the work I do now after involuntary early retirement from the regular corporate workforce.   I am free to do exactly what I do best, on a consulting basis, for just as many hours as the client needs me, and to leave to others  all of the things I used to have to do in a normal full time role but about which I was less knowledgeable or in which I was less interested.    Yes, my compensation (especially loss of company subsidized health benefits) is lower per hour and lower in total because of more limited hours, but the satisfaction is greater.

To be or not to be, that is the question. Tis it better to protect the rights of terrorists who would kill hundreds, thousands, tens of thousands or even a million or more American and gain the approval of liberal Americans and foreigners or tis it better to protect the lives, liberty and pursuit of happiness of the American people and American national security?

So far how the Obama administration would resolve those questions is not clear, as thus far we have seen a tilt, a pretty noticeable tilt in the direction of protecting the rights of the terrorists at the expense of America and Americans. The administration has only balked when an uproar of voices by the citizens of America, as in the case of KSM being tried in civilian criminal court near Ground Zero in Manhattan, woke up President Obama and his advisers to reality. Reading Miranda rights to a terrorist while an ongoing terror threat investigation is taking place, as in the recent underwear airliner bomber does not provide evidence that this administration is making the safety of Americans and America as job #1. The White House seems more like a public defender's social justice organization to ensure that terrorists and terror suspects are given the best possible treatment.

Perhaps the President, the Constitutional scholar, should reread the US Constitution to see what the chief responsibilities of the President are to get a clue as to which track to follow.

I greatly admire this administration, but this is an enormous problem that they really need to tackle with all their might: not just the overall lack of job opportunities, but the lack of job opportunities for some of the most highly qualified and educated members of society. I keep hearing about creating construction jobs with infrastructure development, but those of us in the professional classes are getting hammered as well and yet I see no assistance.  Architects and lawyers are but two of the professional careers that are just being crushed in this recession.

The biggest problem with being "overqualified" is the reality that very, very few companies will even consider people with experience. All anyone needs is a chance whether they are experienced or not.
Most companies now seem to be reluctant to hire anyone who has not done the exact job for someone else. They seem to think anyone incapable of adapting. Silly point as every company's ethics and operations vary wildly from one another.
Of course with so many twenty-somethings making hiring decisions, one cannot expect them to comprehend or relate to people they consider to be the same generation as their parents.

If our government continues to fail to live up to our founding principles, then America is no more. We endured many long years of extra-Constitution, illegal acts perpetrated by the previous administration and its agents — none of which made us more secure (quite the contrary), and all of which diminished our moral standing in the world.

How many more dishonorable years will be added to that shameful recent past?

The damage done by thirty years of Conservative ascendency cannot be undone in fourteen months.  I am astonished at the success this administration has had in so short a time.  I would remind critics, especially those who seize on any excuse to attack this President, of the Bush Administration's eight-year effort to eviscerate the Constitution.  That this Justice Department is filled with lawyers is no surprise.  The surprise, and a happy one, is that they are not ruled and overruled by ideologues with no respect for law.

And there is the problem of the 'entitlement mentality' that says when they start their career, they are to be the one IN CHARGE and not the worker bee.

The article decribes the jobs now held by 2 people:

(1) Mr. Carroll, 31, quickly set about revamping the four-person department,

Ergo, he is the one in charge of the department and has subordinate employees.

(2) a human resources director who once oversaw that domain for 5,000 employees but is now dealing with just 65.

DIRECTOR - not an assistant, not personnel clerk but the DIRECTOR

(3) Jackie Swanson, 44, accepted a part-time job in May as a facilities manager

So after the jobs are decribed as leading a 4 person department, being the director and being the sole manager, we get the inevitable whiney post from the fresh out of school claiming that such as he/she are perfectly qualified for those jobs with the following:

13.Shira

While it's great that companies have been able to hire overqualified workers, it's been fairly unfortunate for THOSE of US JUST OUT OF SCHOOL and looking for entry level jobs. While MY CLASSMATES AND I may be PERFECTLY QUALIFIED FOR some of THE JOBS DESCRIBED in this article, we're being passed over for people with more experience

And then there is # 18. Adam L. also complaining at starting at the bottom of the hierarchy learning the business when he writes:

"I graduated from college in May 2008, just as things were really started to tank. I temped for a year before being hired for a permanent position with a local construction materials distributor. I do everything from designing and updating the company's website to handling most promotional correspondence to picking up goods from the warehouse to making deliveries in the company van. Did I envision myself as, essentially, a blue collar worker when I graduated? No"

And there, in one paragraph #13 demonstrates the over-blown sense of entitlement without any accomplishments. In 30+ years of practicing labor law, I have never seen ANY company put a wet-behind-ears brand new graduate with the ink-still-wet-on-their-diploma "In Charge" of anything at those kind of jobs. And it doesn't matter if the company was Fortune 50 or a Mom 'n Pop with 5 employees.

Brand-new straight-out-of-schoolers with no-experience do NOT get put in charge of anything. And 20 or 30 years ago they didn't expect to be put in charge or supervising anyone. These grandiose ideas are the result of my generation's telling their progeny that they were all Einsteins and #1 at everything!

And what did #18 expect? That he would get to sit in the office with a secretary and make decisions about running a business that he knows nothing about? LOL!!!! No business owner with more brain cells than a gnat is going to let him do that. He really needs to so get over the idea that he is above doing any and all work that a business needs done and the he will never ever actually have to get his hands dirty.

A year or so ago, I watched a neighbor of mine when he walked in to one of the stores of his $45,000,000 a year business with 90+ stores. He just stopped in on a Sunday afternoon with his wife after they had been out to dinner when he realized the store was mobbed and extremely short staffed. He headed back into the beverage cooler and started stocking beer and pop onto the shelves - and stayed at the job for close to 3 hours until it was done. He personally was hauling boxes and and shoving things on the shelves. And his wife went to the storeroom and began shifting stock to the floor and stocking shelves.

If the head of such a business can do that - and he made each of his sons learn the business by doing the daily grunt work - I can assure #18 that he is doing exactly the level of work at which is currently comptent and no one will put him in charge until he learns the business and the company.

One can not say that those described in the article are truly 'under-employed.' They are using the skills for which they trained. They may not be getting the money they want and they may not have the size of the operation they want and they may not have as many underlings as they BUT they ARE employed in their fields. "Under-employed' is the former university porfessor in Switzerland who moved home to the US - and has only found 2 jobs: (a) working in a convenience store stocking shelves and then (b) driving a bus for the regional bus system.

Bottom line is too many people have degrees where there simply are not enough jobs needing their fancy skills. The demand for BAs, MAs, MBAs etc is quite finite but the production of people with such degrees vastly exceeds the number of jobs.

A whole lot of people - and particularly #13 and #18 - need to downscale their expectations and recognize that they are not as unique and wonderful in the job market as they think they are.

As regards targeting individuals for drone strikes, I think that it should be allowed as long as the individuals don't suffer. Drone munitions should utilize a dart gun type system for lethal injection. Actually blowing them up with a hellfire missile seems cruel and unusual.

I hope that more companies will focus on the lessons of this article. There is incredible talent available in this market. You need to focus on the abilities of the person, not what they have done in the past. Most employers are terrified of making hiring decisions and so they protect themselves by listing job requirements. A gutsy boss will look for the fit of the job applicant and the job -- which is much harder than focusing on previous experience. The boss also has to have the self-confidence to hire someone who is as good or better than themselves. Many look for weaker candidates since they are afraid of the competition. When I hear an employer say s/he can't find good candidates, generally one of two things are happening: they aren't paying enough or they can't evaluate the job applicants. It's generally the latter.

Hearing Attorney General say it didn't matter whether Osama Bin Laden would be given a civilian trial and charged with felonies vs terrorism because "he'll never be taken alive" sent chills through my spine.

Obama's plan allows for the possibility that Osama Bin Laden, one of the worst mass murderers of all time, will be found NOT GUILTY because a technicality or perhaps because he was placed under duress.

Here's where you lose me as a supporter, Obama. I rode your train long enough. If I leave your bumper sticker on my car another day, I feel like a traitor to the great city of New York.
